import React from "react"; import Carousel from "./Carousel"; function CaseSF(props) { return (
Sugar {"&"} Flower
  • Client: Spec Work
  • Timing: 2022
  • Duration: 3 Months
  • My Role: UX/UI Designer
The Backstory

To further develop my practical UX/UI Design skills, I completed a self-directed spec project for a mock business, “Sugar {"& "}Flower”. The inspiration for this project came when I was placing an order for a custom cake for my sister{"’"}s birthday and found that the ordering experience could be improved.

Level Up

By focusing on a single feature design, I was able to further develop the following practical skills:

Sketch {"&"} Figma - I gained practical knowledge and experience with both Sketch {"&"} Figma working on this project and an understanding of the advantages to using each respectively.

UI Best Practices - While designing the experience of the stepper, I spent time researching UI Best Practices in great detail. In performing this research, I gained invaluable knowledge on the intricacies of UI and Material Design.

User Personas - This project provided a perfect opportunity to build upon my experience in crafting User Personas. I got the chance to consider the experience for 2 distinct user groups, delineate the requirement of each group and formulate a hypothesis to solve for a varied list of user needs.

Problem to Solve {"&"} Core Considerations

Mock Brief: Sugar {"&"} Flower, a locally-owned cake shop wanted to increase sales of their custom cakes. They felt that the process for placing an order could be simplified/automated. Their website did include a shopping cart, but to order a custom cake, customers online were pointed to get in touch with the store directly, where the order would be taken manually by staff. A key insight they shared was that Instagram was quickly becoming their largest source of new customers, as the platform did an amazing job of showcasing the visual appeal of their cakes.

The problem of “How to improve the process for ordering a custom cake?” was clear, and to start answering that question, I began with noting the following core considerations:

  • - Improving the process of ordering a custom cake carried different meaning depending on the user (customer vs. shop employee vs shop owner)
  • - They already had a functional website with a shopping cart that could be leveraged towards a solution
  • - There was an opportunity to capitalize on the visual appeal of their cakes to enhance the ordering experience

{/*
Research {"&"} Inspiration

  • - Completed competitive analysis of process for taking custom cake orders online, noting key criteria from the experience like complexity, info capture, and use of visuals by competitors
  • - Researched other “made-to-order” online order experiences for inspiration (Domino’s Pizza Builder App, Nike By You Custom Shoes)
  • - Conducted informal iinterviews with actual cake shop/bakery owners

Personas {"&"} Use Cases

Early on, I created user personas to apply user context to the problem. Key design criteria that surfaced from the use cases I had developed were:

  • - Ordering process needed to be simple to understand/use
  • - Should demand low time/energy investment from a user
  • - An option for immediate 2-way communication should be available during the process
  • - Guidance/recommendations should be included where unfamiliar options are presented
  • - All customization options that are available should be clearly communicated in the experience
  • - There should be a visual representation of the cake(s) showing customizations as they are applied (similar to Nike and Domino{"’"}s)
  • - Changes to product availability need to be effectively communicated during the ordering process
  • - Ideally the ordering mechanism can connect with CRM and Inventory Management systems

Ideation {"&"} Iterative Sketching

  • - Taking inspiration from Domino{"'"}s and Nike, began by defining a high-level user flow, organizing the content into a series of steps
  • - Considered various UI including forms, carousel layouts, and horizontal/vertical steppers
  • - Determined optimal layout for steps would be a vertical Stepper UI
  • - Completed additional research on UI patterns and best practices for usage (fields, checkboxes, drop-down menus, etc.)

Low/Medium Wireframing

  • - Used low and med-fi wires to improve cohesion, and create consistency across each step
  • - Paid particular attention to designing the interactions for a user moving back and forth between the steps, determining what affordances and feedback needed to be incorporated in to the experience to reduce friction

*/}
Final Design

  • - I created an aesthetic inspired by brands like Ladurée, and Fortnum {"&"} Mason, which informed aspects of the visual design like type, colour palette, arch motif, etc.
  • - Established type styles, colour palette, buttons styles, states, and sourced UI elements to arrive at final design

{/* */}
Outcomes

The first phase of the project provided the opportunity to create a preliminary design solution. Prior to implementation, a working prototype can now be built off this initial design in order to begin user testing.

Next Steps

Had the project been for a real client, I would continue with the following next steps:

  • - Build a full prototype of the feature including all flows.
  • - Perform user testing to determine any pain points in the experience that could be improved upon
  • - Organize results from user testing, identifying design opportunities, prioritize {"&"} group tasks and set a timeline for second phase of design

{/*
Level Up

This project provided the opportunity to narrow my focus and delve deeper as a UX/UI Designer. Since I was able to direct my efforts towards designing a single feature, I was able to advance several skills essential to UX/UI Design.

Hard Skills (Sketch {"&"} Figma) - I gained practical knowledge and experience with both Sketch {"&"} Figma working on this project and an understanding of the advantages to using each respectively.

UI Best Practices - Particularly when it came to designing the components of the stepper, I relied upon resources that spoke to UI Best Practices to help me determine what the best solution could be. In performing this research, I gained invaluable knowledge on the intricacies of UI and Material Design.

User Personas - This project provided a perfect opportunity to build upon my experience in crafting User Personas. To arrive at a design solution, I had to consider the experience for 2 distinct user groups, delineate the requirement of each group and formulate a hypothesis to solve for a varied list of user needs.

*/}
); } export default CaseSF;
